Density-Matrix Time-Resolved Spectra

The time evolution of the spin density matrix \(\rho(t)\) is governed by the Liouville–von Neumann equation with dissipation:

\[\frac{d\rho}{dt} = -\frac{i}{\hbar} [\hat{H}, \rho] + \mathcal{R}[\rho]\]

where \(\hat{H}\) is the system Hamiltonian and \(\mathcal{R}[\rho]\) is the relaxation superoperator.

The relaxation superoperator \(\mathcal{R}[\rho]\) accounts for four physically distinct processes that govern population and coherence dynamics in time-resolved EPR (see more details in Relaxation Parameters and Initial States):

  • Free probabilities: thermalizing transitions between eigenstates obeying detailed balance,

  • Driven probabilities: coherent or incoherent microwave-induced transitions,

  • Out probabilities: irreversible population loss (e.g., radiative or non-radiative decay),

  • Dephasing rates: pure dephasing between energy levels.

These processes are encoded in the Lindblad master equation, which provides the explicit form of \(\mathcal{R}[\rho]\):

\[\mathcal{R}[\rho] = \sum_k \left( \hat{L}_k \rho \hat{L}_k^\dagger - \frac{1}{2} \{ \hat{L}_k^\dagger \hat{L}_k, \rho \} \right)\]

In addition to the four standard contributions, MarS supports user-defined superoperators, allowing custom relaxation, or phenomenological models to be incorporated directly into \(\mathcal{R}[\rho]\).

Two computational strategies are available for time propagation:

  • Rotating Wave Approximation (RWA) The Hamiltonian is transformed into a frame rotating at the excitation frequency, and fast-oscillating terms are discarded. This yields a time-independent effective Liouvillian, enabling efficient simulation. (see details in Rotating Wave Approximation)

  • Full Propagator Construction The complete Liouvillian is used to construct the exact evolution superoperator (see details in Propagator-Based Density Matrix Evolution):

    \[\mathcal{U}(\Delta t) = \exp\!\big( \mathcal{L} \, \Delta t \big), \quad \text{where} \quad \mathcal{L}[\rho] = -\frac{i}{\hbar}[\hat{H}, \rho] + \mathcal{R}[\rho]\]

While RWA reduces computational cost, it suffers from limitations:

  • The electron Zeeman interaction must be isotropic or close to isotropic: \(\hat{G}_x = g \mu_B \hat{S}_x\), etc.

  • The static part of the Hamiltonian \(\hat{F}\) (all terms except Zeeman) must commute with \(\hat{G}_z\): \([\hat{F}, \hat{G}_z] = 0\).

  • The relaxation superoperator only couples matrix elements \(\rho_{ij}\) and \(\rho_{kl}\) when \(i - j = k - l\).

All relaxation terms and jump operators alike are first defined in the user-specified basis (e.g., "zfs", "eigen") and then transformed into the Hamiltonian eigenbasis.
